message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sphincter of Oddi regulates the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the duodenum. The hormone cholecystokinin (CCK) released by I cells in the duodenum in the presence of fatty acids is the most effective cause of sphincter relaxation. Therefore, option (A) is the correct answer. Option (B) is incorrect because the sphincter is not contracted between meals. Option (C) is incorrect as opioid receptors do not play a role in sphincter relaxation. Option (D) is also incorrect as there is no hormone released by M cells that regulates the function of the sphincter of Oddi.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of fatty acids in the duodenum triggers the release of cholecystokinin (CCK), which causes the I cells of the duodenum to release secretin, a hormone that ultimately leads to sphincter relaxation. Therefore, option (A) is the correct answer. Option (B) is incorrect, as the sphincter is actually relaxed between meals. Option (C) is incorrect, as stimulation of opioid receptors would lead to sphincter constriction rather than relaxation. Option (D) is also incorrect, as there is no hormone released specifically by the M cells of the duodenum that causes sphincter relaxation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sphincter of Oddi, which controls the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the duodenum, is regulated by various factors. Option (A) is correct as the hormone cholecystokinin (CCK), released by I cells in the duodenum in response to the presence of fatty acids, is the most effective cause of sphincter relaxation. Option (B) is incorrect as the sphincter is actually relaxed during meals, not contracted. Option (C) is incorrect as opioid receptors can actually cause sphincter contraction. Option (D) is also incorrect as M cells in the duodenum primarily produce hormones involved in regulating immune responses.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The I cells of the duodenum release cholecystokinin (CCK) in response to fatty acids, causing relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi, allowing for the release of bile and digestive enzymes into the small intestine. Knowing this, option A is the correct answer as it describes the regulation of the function of the sphincter. Option B is incorrect as the sphincter is normally relaxed between meals. Option C is incorrect as opioids, if anything, tend to cause contraction of the sphincter. Option D is incorrect as there are no M cells in the duodenum.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The statement that best describes the regulation of the sphincter is (A). The hormone released by the I cells of the duodenum in the presence of fatty acids is cholecystokinin (CCK), which causes relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi, allowing for the release of bile and pancreatic enzymes into the small intestine. This can be important during ERCP, as cannulation of the pancreatic duct may be difficult if the sphincter is constricted. Option (B) may be true, but it does not address the specific situation in this patient. Option (C) is not accurate, as opioid receptor stimulation causes sphincter constriction. Option (D) may be partly true, as there are various hormones and neurotransmitters that can regulate the sphincter, but CCK is the most effective cause of relaxation.

Option A is correct because the hormone cholecystokinin, released by I cells of the duodenum in the presence of fatty acids, is the most effective cause of sphincter relaxation. Option B is incorrect because the sphincter is relaxed between meals. Option C is incorrect because sphincter relaxation is not enhanced by stimulation of opioid receptors, but rather is inhibited. Option D is incorrect because there is no hormone released by M cells of the duodenum that plays a role in regulating the sphincter of Oddi.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sphincter of Oddi is a muscular valve that controls the flow of bile and pancreatic juice into the duodenum. It is normally contracted between meals, and sphincter relaxation is enhanced via stimulation of CCK receptors. However, the answer options do not match these facts. Option A is the only option that mentions a hormone (CCK) and its effect on sphincter relaxation, making it the correct answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Option A is correct, as the hormone cholecystokinin (CCK), released by I cells of the duodenum in the presence of fatty acids, causes relaxation of the sphincter of Oddi. Option B is incorrect, as the sphincter is normally contracted during meals to prevent reflux of duodenal contents into the biliary and pancreatic ducts. Option C is incorrect, as opioid receptors are not involved in sphincter relaxation. Option D is also incorrect, as no hormone released by the M cells of the duodenum is known to cause sphincter relaxation.
